content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my preference for predictability and avoiding risks, I would choose strategy B for this game. This is because, over a large number of rounds, the payoff difference between choosing R and B when playing against an equally cautious opponent (as described) is minimal.

In fact, if we consider the expected value in each round, it's slightly better to play B since you earn 40$ every time both players choose B, while earning only 45$ when both pick R (a difference of -5$). However, this difference is offset by the potential for a higher total payoff when your opponent deviates from their expected strategy and chooses R.

Since we don't know our opponent's strategy and are assuming they are equally cautious, it's more likely that they will also choose B most of the time. This means that there is a higher probability of earning 40$ per round compared to the potential for a one-time payout of 35$. Over 75 rounds, the difference in expected value between choosing R and B becomes even smaller, making B the more conservative choice.

I will choose B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
I will choose B again{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.
I will choose R this time, to see if my opponent deviates from their strategy and chooses R as well{R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 35$. Please play the next round.
